qas.question: What is the link between North and South America called?
In which period did North and South America become linked?
The Pliocene saw the end of what fauna in South America?
The Mediterranean was created by the collision of Europe and what?
What period came after the Pliocene?
What completely ended South America's marsupial faunas?
What formed to linked North and South America in the Quaternary Period?
What began at the with the Pilocene?
How often does the cycle of rising sea levels repeat?

context: South America became linked to North America through <a0_0>the <b6_0>Isthmus of Panama<b6_0/><a0_0/> during the <a1_0>Pliocene<a1_0/>, bringing a nearly complete end to South America's distinctive <a2_0>marsupial faunas<a2_0/><b5_0>. The formation of the Isthmus<b5_0/> had major consequences on global temperatures, since warm equatorial ocean currents were cut off and an Atlantic cooling cycle began, with cold Arctic and Antarctic waters dropping temperatures in the now-isolated Atlantic Ocean. <a3_0>Africa<a3_0/>'s collision with Europe formed the Mediterranean Sea, cutting off the remnants of the Tethys Ocean. Sea level changes exposed the land-bridge between Alaska and Asia. Near the end of the Pliocene, about 2.58 million years ago (the start of <a4_0>the Quaternary Period<a4_0/>), <b7_0>the current ice age began.<b7_0/> The polar regions have since undergone repeated cycles of glaciation and thaw, repeating <b8_0>every 40,000–100,000 years.
